A Space Admin, who is not a full confluence Admin, attempted to goto http://wiki.customink.office/confluence/spaces/viewstylesheet.action?key=PA

Not Permitted

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-19375].
  {panel}

A user was unable to create a bookmark in Confluence using the bookmarklet in Firefox on [Mac] Snow Leopard.  When the user clicked "Bookmark in Confluence", the "Add Bookmark" screen that appeared lacked any [Confluence] Space options in the Space dropdown list.  Additionally, the "Save" and "Cancel" buttons are not visible.

I was able to reproduce the empty Space dropdown by attempting to add a bookmark using the bookmarklet while not logged into Confluence using Firefox 3.6 on Windows Vista.  I was able to see the "Save" and "Cancel" buttons, and received the following error message after successfully passing the CAPTCHA:

"The following errors need to be fixed before the bookmark can be saved

    * Please select a space for the bookmark.
    * You must enter a spaceKey."

h1. Workaround
The user has confirmed that if they are logged into Confluence _*prior*_ to attempting to add a bookmark to Confluence - the Space dropdown is populated and the buttons are visible.

h1. Suggestion
It would be nice if the page provided information to indicate that the user has to be logged into Confluence in order to add a bookmark to it.  Looks like that indication can be keyed off the Space list being empty.
fields.summary: Bookmarklet: Provide Information when Spaces Dropdown is not populated

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-19324].
  {panel}

If an attacker has gained system admin access to Confluence, they can upload a plugin which can perform malicious activities with the same permissions as the Confluence application (e.g. write files to locations on the filesystem where the Confluence application user has write permission).

There is currently no way for Confluence administrators to restrict the powers of plugin code running in Confluence.

One potential solution is to define a [Java Security Policy|http://articles.techrepublic.com.com/5100-10878_11-6178805.html] which can be implemented with the Java SecurityManager. Previously we had an unsupported document which described how to run Confluence with a policy that restricted some access on the filesystem, but not much else:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONF29/Java+Policy+Security+with+Confluence
http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DISC/Java+Policy+Security+with+Confluence (currently locked as Obsolete)

It would be good if this document was extended to limit functionality further, and tested properly so it could be supported by Atlassian for use in production. It could provide a good way for the administrator to limit the powers available to plugins and provide a layer of security when installing new plugins.

Another related issue is CONF-20287, restricting the ability to upload plugins through the web interface.

h5. problem description:
Confluence fails to render .mov file *only* in _Snow Leopard AND Safari_ (tested in Safari 4.0.3) - the browser will renders a big quick time logo with question mark over it ([screenshot|^safari.jpg]). The browser is not able to locate the file either via linking as if the file does not exist.

It works in Firefox in Snow Leopard and in Mac 10.5.8's Safari.

Whomever is working on this ticket, please make sure that the fix in Confluence 3.3m1 gets applied in 3.2.x.

Very useful would be to have the possibility to REMOTELY (via webservice remote api) define/retrieve metadata key/value pair OUTSIDE wiki content, in order
- to protect them
- to be outside content (they are data about data)
- enable more formal location of metadata

1. force user to compile metadata
2. auto compile metadata
3. allow remote API to quick fetch metadata programmatically and related content

thanks

When building a custom dashboard with macros e.g. using Theme Builder the macro recently-updated-dashboard cannot be filtered for special groups of spaces like favourites or new spaces.

Hi,

in our Wiki, users often use arrows in the text. Confluence does not have built-in arrows, so they just use {{-->}} which is displayed as -->, but these "fake" arrows look really bad.

Therefore, it would be great if Confluence had a feature to convert these "fake" arrows into real arrow symbols. Confluence already does something similar with dashed where {{\-\-}} and {{\-\-\-}} is converted into the real dashes.

As a workaround, I created a user macro {{\{rarr\}}} that creates the HTML entity {{→}}, but it is not very intuitive for users to use {{\{rarr\}}} instead of {{-->}}.

I really hope that a feature like this could be added to Confluence because it would be a nice improvement for "every day usability". :-)

The developer docs for creating a language pack are out of date and scattered all over the place. They need to be cleaned up and pulled together into a cohesive guide.

Existing docs:
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Language+Module
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Creating+A+New+Confluence+Translation
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Updating+A+Confluence+Translation
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Translations+for+the+Rich+Text+Editor
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DISC/Translations+for+Confluence+Releases
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DISC/Confluence+3.2+Translations
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DISC/Language+Pack+Translations

Tasks:
* Create a single 'Creating a Language Pack' doc
(i) Properties are not all implemented in ConfluenceActionSupport_KEY.properties anymore (although it can be done this way), rather each bundled plugin has it's own properties file now that is referenced as a resource in the atlassian-plugin.xml, e.g. 'tinymce_fr_FR.properties'
(i) The recommended process for creating a language pack should be to take an existing language pack, update it with their own translations and repackage it. Unfortunately there is no existing English language pack, so it may be difficult to determine what each of the key-value properties relates to. The only way to figure this out is by downloading the plugin (e.g. TinyMCE plugin) and checking the i18n property file or by trial and error (e.g. sticking values in the key and seeing what changes). 
(i) Even better would be to update the example language pack (en_AU.zip) file on the http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Creating+A+New+Confluence+Translation by downloading each of the plugins and copying the data from the properties file of each plugin into the example language pack. Developers could then use this as a base.
=> (!) Use http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Language+Module as the base and merge in content from http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Creating+A+New+Confluence+Translation
** Describe structure of the atlassian-plugin.xml file.
(i) dashboard-macros plugin = semi-core functionality, such as 'Recently Updated', macrosadvanced = macro browser, macrofallback = not a plugin, corresponds to macrofallback.properties
** 'Language Pack Overview' section - Remove the blurb 
** 'Language Pack Overview' section - In the table, the ConfluenceActionSupport Properties file only covers the translation of Confluence core. Add text to mention this and add a table entry to cover the i18n.properties files for each of the plugin resources with Confluence, e.g. i18n-tinymce, i18n-linkbrowser, i18n-jiraissues, etc... (see atlassian-plugin.xml in attached french translation for full list)
** 'ConfluenceACtionSupport Properties File' section --- The Java Properties file contains key value pairs for each string in Confluence _Core_ and each string in every plugin...
** From http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Creating+A+New+Confluence+Translation Step 9 --- Replace with Java instructions: 'jar -cvf' (requires JDK)
** From http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Creating+A+New+Confluence+Translation Step 10 --- Can replace with inclusion from 'Installing a Language Pack' doc
=> (!) Deprecate http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Creating+A+New+Confluence+Translation

* Change http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DISC/Language+Pack+Translations into a community translations page
=> (!) Remove content on installation of a plugin, however leave the list of community translations.
=> (!) Remove content on developing a language pack. Link to it instead.
=> (!) Remove 'Translations of the Rich Text Editor' section.
NB: Process for submitting a language pack is correct.

* Review http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Translations+for+the+Rich+Text+Editor
The content in this can probably be pulled into the new 'Creating a Language Pack' doc. The instructions are correct, but they are not specific to the RTE.

=> (!) Deprecate?

* Update http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CONFDEV/Updating+A+Confluence+Translation

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-19079].
  {panel}

I need to refer to the same attachment (such as image files), from many other pages. At the same time as the wiki evolves the names of pages change frequently, including the names of pages were attachments reside. Also the file names of attachments can change, while the contents is "conceptually" the same (such as new versions of the same document usually has new file names). Currently, every time i change the name of the page that includes the attachment, it breaks the "hard coded" links to attachments everywhere else on the wiki. Also, whenever, i upload a new version of an attachment, i need to make first make sure that it has the file name of the already uploaded file -- although outside of the wiki, this may not be the case anymore. A way to create a symbolic name for a local URL would be most helpful. 

For example:

Instead of: !1.3. Meta models^tmp116.jpg!

It should be possible to indicate the following:

On the 1.3. Meta models page:
{alias meta-models}

On a different page it should then be possible to refer to the attachment as follows:
meta-models^tmp116.jpg


Ideally, when uploading an image it should also be possible to create an alias. For example:

the image tmp116.jpg should have the alias: agent-meta-model

the full link to the attachment should then be:

meta-models^agent-meta-model

Such an approach would allow changing the name of pages and the name of attachments, as they get uploaded, while preserving the functionality of all links to them in the wiki.

If such an alias features is implemented, then one issue to consider is centralized management of alias to URLs/attachments, which could be done instead or in addition to managing of alias within relevant pages.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-19054].
  {panel}

To improve Confluence's search, please provide an option to resolve all {include} and {excerpt-include} macro content before Confluence indexes whole page content.

h4. Problem

When Confluence indexes page content for searches, it doesn't resolve the content of these inclusions into the page first. Hence, when the user attempts to search for a page based on a term that's actually part of an inclusion's content, then the page that 'hosts' the inclusion will not show up in the search results.

As far as the user is concerned, those terms _are_ on the page when they view it. It's not until the user looks at the page's Wiki Markup when they'll realise that the content is only being referenced via an inclusion macro (and why the search didn't retrieve the 'host' page).

It's often more useful to see _the names/titles_ of these 'host' pages in search results, rather than those of the actual 'inclusion pages' themselves, since 'inclusion pages' (and titles) are typically out of context.

h4. Solution

To improve Confluence's search efficacy, Confluence could provide an admin console option to makes it resolve the content of all \{include\} and \{excerpt-include\} macros first, before it indexes the whole page content.

If Confluence could resolve all inclusions before indexing whole page content, this will provide the following benefits:
* If a user searches for text contained within \{include\} or \{excerpt-include\} macros, the names (and links) of pages that include this content will appear in the search results, rather than just the 'inclusion pages' further down the list of search results.
\\ \\
* If a space uses the new 'Documentation Theme' and a user searches for text contained within \{include\} or \{excerpt-include\} macros using the search box in the TOC column (for example, any one of our product documentation spaces on [CAC|http://confluence.atlassian.com/]), the pages that include this content will appear in the search results, rather than not at all.
\\ \\
*Why would these searches show no results?*
\\ \\
The Documentation Theme requires a 'root page' within the space (from which the TOC is generated) to be set. When you start viewing pages within the space, the search box in the TOC column (by design) will only search pages contained within the 'root page' hierarchy. 'Inclusion pages', however, are typically kept outside this hierarchy to prevent them appearing in the TOC. Hence, if you use this Documentation Theme search box to look for terms contained within an 'inclusion page', you're likely to get no results.
fields.summary: Confluence search results should include content added to page via the  {include} and {excerpt-include} macros
